course.subject: ENVR
course.name: The Sustainable Citizen
course.description: This course examines threats to our civilization's sustainability. What does science tell us about these threats? How does our consumption and lifestyle drive these threats?  What can we, as citizens, do to make our civilization more sustainable? At the end of the course, students should be able to provide a balanced and accurate explanation of the scientific issues and the action we can take. For students in their first and second year of study or those with approval from instructor for enrolling in the course.

reviews.author: Sabina
reviews.comment_content:
Huge variety of issues on environment and sustainability. It may be difficult to connect everything together.
The powerpoints are mainly facts which are a little bit boring.
reviews.comment_teaching: What the professor said is just mainly following what have been written in the powerpoints. If the professor has enough time, he will talk more about the issues in details. But may go through the powerpoints really briefly sometimes. You may still cannot answer those questions on the first page of each powerpoints which are said to be important by the professor even if you attend the lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
PRS
Group project (presentation, powerpoint, poster, peer evaluation)
Midterm
Exam

PRS is important in this course as it contributes to more than 10%, you have to prepare for it by watching the movies, reading the articles given by the professor through canvas a week before, the mean of each PRS is usually high. If you get more than 1 MC wrong, you will be below mean for that PRS.
Midterm is for you to get familiar with the format of exam so it only takes about 10%
Midterm and exam have the same format which contains two parts. Part A is short questions while part B is essay. You have to remember the meanings of all the vocabulary  in the vocab list and some facts stated in the powerpoints, but usually it is hard to know what facts to remember as there are too many. The essay part is not difficult.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload of the PRS may be heavy sometimes for you may have to watch the whole movie, or read 3 long articles for 1 PRS. There are about 8 PRS in total.
Group project won't be a burden if your groupmates are willing to work.

reviews.author: Nathan CC
reviews.title: Worst grade CC course I have ever studied in UST
reviews.comment_content: Content was Ok-ish. The professor taught us something that was at least mattered to us. The content was extremely boring. Most of the class was not paying attention during the lesson.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor himself was friendly and kind. The most intolerable part was those 2 smart-asses TA. They gave score based on their own discretion regardless of the facts and truth. My friend got at least 5 more points back because of their crappy work on grading the final papers.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was terrible. I got above mean 5-6% in both Final and mid-term. My final grade was B-. (I got C+ originally and I had to beg professor to give me a B-). Most of my friends I knew who took this course got C+. Those who said the grading of this course was good were either lying or 打手。

Please deliberate before taking this course based on my heartbroken experience.
reviews.comment_workload:
Tons of workload. There were iprs questions in each lesson. I had to watch some videos first before class to complete the iprs questions.
Apart from that, I still got 1 presentation and 1 final group poster which were time-consuming. Professor and TAs didn't tell us what exactly they were looking for in the projects. So good luck trying to please them.
Mid-term and final exam were just memorizing contest. I had to memorize literally all the content of the ppt.

reviews.author: elaine_girl

reviews.comment_workload: quite heavy as every week's lecture pre-lecture reading is required for you to take the quizzes

reviews.author: Alpha703
reviews.title: Meaningful course
reviews.comment_content:
Generally speaking, this course is all about introducing different perspectives to inspect a wide range of sustainability issues(particularly environmental sustainability), and learning about the different stakeholders and their impact to the issues in-depth. The  value, interest relationship and attitude behind the scenes are emphasized. I found the contents quite meaningful and effectively broadened our horizons and can view things more in-depth.

Lecture plan, keyword list and syllabus attached.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Gibson tried very hard to stimulate class discussions and encouraged students to exchange views. He prepares a lot of reading materials(TED talks, chinadialogue, youtube videos...) that enable our deeper understanding of the topic.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair(He stated that he follow the official guidelines to give grades). Unfortunately I messed up on some critical parts in the project and in allocation of time to study the final exam so the grade is not that good for me, but in general paying a reasonable amount of effort in revision and project will yield you a B+ or above.

Midterm (10%) Mean 58%/100 Me: 79%/100 SD:(Forgot)
Final exam(40%) Mean: 74.4/120 Me: 82/120 SD:(Forgot)
Project (30%) Mean: 21.3/30 Me: 17.99/30 SD: ?
IMPORTANT: After the project you need to write a reflection of the project which counts for 5 out of 30 project marks. Don't hea write it like me or else you lose those 5 marks and get below mean like me.
PRS (20%) Mean:? Me: 85.7/100
PRS marks calculation: Discard the PRS marks in add-drop period and the 2 lowest marks. The remaining marks will be adjusted to a linear scale from <50% giving zero to 100% giving full marks.

My grade: B
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload can be somewhat heavy. Since project groups are formed early and group members have to sit together in the course, most works(not just the project) in this course can be coordinated and shared within the group, so good luck avoiding freeriders :)

Attendance and PRS: Usually occur mid-class. You need to watch the reading materials(can require up to 2 hours) before the lessons and then answer PRS questions related to them. After project groups are formed, some groups will coordinate one member to read the materials and carry the PRS, so it depends on whether your teammates want to take up this task lol.

Project: Heavy workload if you want A range because of its large weighting in the grade. A somewhat in-depth investigation on a sustainability topic followed by a ppt presentation and poster presentation. PPT presentation is mainly to describe the problem and propose some directions for the in-class discussion that follows, so the workload for this is not big. Poster have to be very detailed and also good-looking (Infographics design with Adobe AI recommended, many groups use it), so reserve a lot of time to do it.

Midterm/Final: Consists of two parts. Part A are short questions that usually listed in the first few slides of lecture notes and also the keyword list. You can (and you should) prepare them in advance, need half to full week to do so. Part B=DSE English writing. If you are good at high school English writing this part is easy. Note that you can write as many words you can but can't write on more than 1 piece of single-lined paper provided.

reviews.author: minna_
reviews.comment_content:
Professor teaches different environmental topics for each lecture.
Almost anything you can relate to the environment will be a topic, for example water, waste, global warming etc. They are quite interesting and many of them are inspiring, which makes you reflect on your own behaviours.
reviews.comment_teaching: Since one topic is taught for each lecture, professor actually rushes over all the content, so basically when you study for mid-term and final exam, you probably will not remember much. There are many statistics and graphs in the lecture notes but professor will not go over them in details.
reviews.comment_grading: From my experience, grading depends much on final exam, which means if you perform well in final exam, you will have a good grade, provided that your performance is average in group project and PRS quizzes.
reviews.comment_workload:
Below are excerpted from pre-lecture notes:
1) PRS quizzes in class (20%). There will be between 8 and 10 of these. A student’s score will be calculated as the average score after leaving out the two tests on which he/she performed worst. It will then be adjusted to a linear scale from 50% (or below) giving zero to 100% giving full marks.

2) Groups of 4 or 5 students working on a sustainability topic.
a. Lead class discussion of topic. (10%)
b. At end of course exhibit two A3 posters and answer questions about these posters. (15%)
c. Write reflections on their group’s work and poster. (5%)
Marks for ‘b’ will be based on faculty judging the posters and peer review.

3) A one hour mid-course test during a lecture. This test will be in the same format as the end-of-course exam, but half the length.
(10%)

4) A two-hour end-of-course exam. This will comprise:
a. One hour to answer about 10 short factual questions.
b. One hour to answer two questions each of which requires a ‘one page essays’. The structure for these essays will be explained during the lectures. (40%)

reviews.author: kaila
reviews.comment_content: The course if very interesting if you are interested in environmental issues. It focuses on a broad range of environmental issues, from resource depletion to pollution problems and species extinction.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Gibson is a really great teacher. He teaches in a clear and efficient way that allows everyone to understand easily. He is also very willing and patient in answering students' questions and often address them in class.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fair. If you memorise the definitions and answer the in class questions you'll be fine. The professor sometimes include those questions in the exam so you would be wise to prepare for those questions.
reviews.comment_workload: There is quite a bit of workload comparing to other science courses, as there are 10 PRS questions which require you to do some research before attending the class (may be articles or videos). But the professor only counts the best 7 PRS results so it is fairly easy to get a good grade in it. The midterm only counts 10% so you can get a good feel as to how the final exam is like without that much pressure.

reviews.author: 哎呀
reviews.title: Interesting and Useful
reviews.comment_content:
Combine environmental issues with social analysis, like Javon's Paradox.
May have a better understanding about the complexity of solving the problems.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very critical. Gibson has a very wide social network. He invites guest speakers once a week and, fortunately, those are not covered in exam...
Always prompt and patient to reply to emails, and even adjust content when we raise a point and demand it to be discussed in class, like Under the Dome. Half of the class watched it before discussion. Gibson said the knowledge in this documentary was nothing special, yet what makes it outstanding is that it writes more with heart than cool mind. I'd like to say this is a interesting comment.
reviews.comment_grading:
12 PRS counts for 25%. Can search online or ask groupmates. Only top 7 are counted.
Group presentation and poster 5% and 20%. We indicate 5 preference at the very beginning, then in case of exceeding demand for some group, professor will try to mix groupmates with different background.
Midterm 10% 6 short questions and one essay
Final 40% 10 short questions and two essays
reviews.comment_workload:
Depend on your expectation of grade...
The more you want, the harder you'll have to work.

reviews.author: ChuaWanZhen
reviews.title: A good course that allows us to learn a lot
reviews.comment_content: This course introduces various environmental issues and the organizations that are responsible for it. Overall it is an interesting course and we can learn a lot. Topics covered: Energy, Marine habitat and seafood, Environmental problems, planetary limits, climate change, scientific methods, life cycle analysis, gaia hypothesis, sustainable lifestyle, population, global governance, ecological footprint, urban design, air pollution, climate change, water, solid waste management, market, values-stuff sharing
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Gibson is a very engaging professor. He always welcome questions from students and willing to answer them. He himself is always prepared for the lectures and has a wide range of knowledge
reviews.comment_grading: The grading for this course is quite good. So long you pay attention during the lectures and prepare for the answers for the "potential questions" for the midterms and finals, study the keyword list, prepare for the prs quiz and put some effort in your group project, you do not need to worry about the grading
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is pretty heavy, especially when you need to prepare for the PRS quizes. Sometimes the video that we need to watch can last for an hour or more. But the videos are quite interesting

reviews.author: emilychannnn
reviews.comment_content:
Content revolves mainly about the environment (but not the environmental science aspect)
Simple and applicable knowledge for our daily practices.
reviews.comment_teaching: Engaging atmosphere in class. The professor and TA are specially kind and they take questions both in and outside class. They don't mind spending their time in helping students to understand more.
reviews.comment_grading: Better than fair. You work hard and you get what you deserve. If you have paid attention in class and did some revision, it should be easy for you in finals
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy as you have to watch videos/read different lecture related material before going into class.
There are quite a number of PRS sessions throughout the course and as long as you get 7/8(?) right you'll obtain full mark for the % PRS takes in the whole course.
Also you are required to do a short 5-min presentation with your group (that is assigned by the professor) on a topic of your preference. After that you will also be required to do a poster and display it in the classroom by the end of the course.

reviews.author: SmartBee
reviews.title: Good Course
reviews.comment_content: Content is somewhat interesting if you like learning a bit about the environment and what is causing global warming. A lot of the content you have probably seen in high school or just throughout your everyday life.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is engaging and since it is a small classroom most of the students are paying attention and don't chat or sleep. He cracks some jokes form time to time.
reviews.comment_grading:
PRS quizzes are somewhat easy, there are about 10-11 PRS quizzes during the course of the semester but only your best 8 count.
Most people get between 4/5 and 5/5 for the presentation.
The essay/definition grading is very lenient, if you understand the terms and know how to explain it clearly in your own words you will get the points.

Grade Obtained: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
The work load for this course is very acceptable. There are PRS quizzes almost every lecture that are based off of TED Talks or videos given as homework to watch. They are open book and fairly laid-back so you can discuss the answers with your classmates if done so quietly. People also used the transcription of some videos and ted talks in order to try and answer the questions.
There are 2 group projects:
- first is a 5 minute presentation on your topic, worth I think around 5 point (beginning of the semester)
- second is a poster on the same topic, where classmates and professors ask you about your topic, testing your knowledge on your topic. This is worth about 20 points  (end of the semester)
There is a midterm and final, where you are asking 2 essay questions based on the lecture notes as well as 5 definitions.
The workload might seem like a lot but it is relatively easy and spread out during the course of the semester.
